I’m an ex-airforce man with the RCAF. I lived for 6 months in the furthest most northern year round station called CFS Alert. I stayed during the ‘summer’ months in that it was nearly 5 months of straight daylight. Though I was only a Corporal, I managed to experience something I won’t ever forget. This brief experience you had makes me jealous. As someone who can wear the title of “frozen chosen”, I wish I had experienced what you had. It’s true that living up north in the area nearly inhabitable by human life. You get to experience the isolation and the near off planet experience you refer to. I really enjoyed this video. I liked your effort to say you’re a serious channel. But it’s kind of crazy how important it is to prioritize safety over even humour. But, after all the safety briefs. The experience is unreal and will follow me to the grave. I’m glad you show some of the amazing work the scientist are doing there. I was friends with the environmental scientist up there and I felt very vital with how important it was the station worked. Though the work of the scientist at these stations cannot be undervalued, the collective of every person in the arctic is something you’re gifted to experience. I love this video. It helped me relive the experience.

Maybe you're not such a faithless generation after all? Here is the 1st part of the Proof to the Collatz conjecture which absolutely proves there is only one possible way in in any one sequence so no loop is possible as tight as and explained as simply as Euclids proof to the primes though it does have more factors. The other half is on the collatzconjectureproof page on my website which I'm sure you know by now.

In the proof to the Collatz conjecture we use 3 types of odd numbers


A number divisible by 3 (3n) 9,15,2, 27 etc


A 3n+2 11,17, 23, 29...etc


A 3n-2 13, 19, 25, 31...etc




When we do this we spot a pattern.


1. Every division by 2^odd number (2,8,32,128 etc) leads to a 2+1


2. Every division by 2^even number leads to a 2-1.




3. There are 2 functions which lead to the same stop-start value of x only 1234 can satisfy both functions simultaneously.


3x+1÷2^n


3x+1/3÷2^n


Some 2 separate numbers can together satisfy both functions to arrive at the same stop-start number but they cannot be in the same sequence.




Because


For a loop there must be 2 ways in and one way out. This is not possible.


4. A number can have 2 ways in and one way out for example 47 can be reached by 31×3+1÷2 or by 125×3+1÷8 but the 2 ways in cannot happen in the same sequence.


4a. Because both come from an initial number that must be part of the sequence, for example 27 is the starting x which leads to the number 31×3+1÷2=47 but 27 is divisible by 3 so cannot be the arrived at by a descent from 3x+1÷2. 97 is a 3n-2 which cannot be descended into from above because.


4b. A starting x that is a 3n-2 cannot be descended into from above because in order for a 3n-2 to be arrived at by the function 3x+1÷2 it must be arrived at from below because any (3n-2)×3+1÷2 can only happen where that 3n-2 is a lower value than the initial x because in order to arrive at the same slope between x and 2x it must also satisfy the slope between x and 4x (3x+1/3) in a direct descent so therefore any 3n-2 must arrive at most at 2x. So therefore such stop start number would be a 3n+2. If it is a 3n+2 then 2x must at most be 1/2 of 1/4 of 8x which has the same slope as between x and 2x relative to 0 but this is impossible because then the 8x would be 16x relative to the stop start number which is impossible because all divisions by 2^even number (base 4) end in a 3n-2.  ￼


So there can be no descent from higher up it must come from below. There cannot be any number within infinity that can satisfy this requirement because the 1st number to violate the descent to 1234 must theoretically come from above (which I have just shown is impossible) not below because all lower numbers would have already decended to 1234.


4c. No 2 different 3n+2 can descend at the same slope to arrive at the initial value of X see illustration attached.


No 2 3n+2 numbers can both satisfy the same end number after 3x+1÷2^n because any 2 numbers satisfying the function descend at a different slope relative to a direct line to 0 so cannot both arrive at the same slope that is between x and 2x in a direct descent.  So any initial x must have been arrived at from only one possible route, a sequence which must begin at the initial value of x (or lower which as already established is impossible because the theorised 1st number to violate the drop to 1234 cannot be arrived at from below). Also because for any theoretical slope to arrive at the stop-start x which is a 3n+2 it must satisfy 3x+1÷2 from (a) a lower value of x which must have been arrived at from operations of the function beginning at the initial x which means a descent from a higher value of 3x+1 also is impossible because then it cannot also satisfy the function 3x+1/3 to descend into the same slope between 2x and x. If it did arrive from higher it cannot also arrive from lower which is obvious but may not be obvious to anyone under stress.


So no loop is possible arising from any number within infinity for these simple reasons. The Collatz conjecture absolutely definitely cannot have a loop.

As a Canadian who has experienced 40 to 50 below zero centigrade  congratulations on your introduction to the frozen north.  To visit is one thing, to live there is another but you had a heck of a primer.  I have installed and maintained equipment outside at minus 45c below which not much work is done on account of the cold. Steel acts funny at those temperatures and humans generally don't like it. I think the coldest I have ever seen is minus  52c where the drilling rig I was working on shut down for safety. While shut down the boiler used to heat things went down and the mud system froze up. I pity the guys who had to thaw that out but I was lucky I went on days off. My truck ran fine, but the small airlines all shut down so I had to drive to a nearby town and swap my pickup for a rental car and drive home about 5 hours. The rental car was frozen, it had not been plugged it so first it had to spend some time in a heated garage to start it.  In the 4th hour of driving it started running rough due to frozen water in the gas. I made it  a service station, chugging and sputtering,  which sold gas with 10% ethanol in it (a time where little gas blended with alcohol.)

I was an active-duty Marine in the 90's assigned to a unit that supported Artic operations. A trip to the training center mentioned here at 16:54 was deemed as required for any personnel who was appointed to be entering any active operations area in the Artic. Over the course of several months, the installation provided training in the do's and don'ts for every imaginable circumstance that may occur in the extreme environment. In addition to the survival instruction, other training included, but wasn't limited to... rescue (air/sea wreckage), ice breaches (cracks/surfacing submarines/meteorites), Hypothermia treatment (exposure/immersion), and of course battlefield combat (offensive/defensive tactics & strategies). Comparatively speaking, in my opinion, surviving the training was harder than the actual short trip I made to the ice pack.

The twin otter or DeHavilland Canada DHC-6 (affectionately known as the twotter or the dash 6) is a jet aircraft. The engines are turbo props. They use a jet engine to turn the props. So whilst it is powered by propeller, it has a huge amount of power. When you say "propeller aircraft" people have an image of an underpowered little toy. That couldn't be further from the truth. The Twotter is an incredibly capable aircraft. It has between 1100 and 1500 horsepower depending on the variant. It will happily fly in a single engine.

By your passing mention of the Royal Canadian Air Force, and subsequent research, I learned something new about my country's military.

Back in 1968, Canada went through a military restructuring that brought the Royal Canadian Navy, the Canadian Army, and the Royal Canadian Air Force - previously 3 distinct armed forces, much like how they are in the US - under the umbrella of the Canadian Armed Forces - a unified military. The idea was to cut out redundancies in logistics and administration, hopefully making operations combining Air Sea and Land forces more effective, and definitely trimming down the budget while hopefully not having a detrimental effect on quality. Not sure what the current generation of the CAF think about that, but at the time it was ....rather a big deal. Lots of senior commanders who didn't like the reforms were given their retirement paperwork and sent on their way. The RCAF was initially divided into several commands - Mobile Command (also where the army ended up), Maritime Command (also where the navy ended up), Air Defence Command, Air Transport Command and Training Command, but a later restructuring in 1975 brought all aircraft under the new Air Command. (Canada doesn't have any aircraft carriers, so this doesn't generate a weird issue where the ship and crew that carry the planes are under the Maritime Command but the main means of attack that ship carries is under the Air Command. Not sure what the implications are for helicopters that operate alongside Destroyers and the like, though)

What I didn't know is that in 2013, the traditional names of these services were restored. They're still legally different branches of a single unified military, so you don't get the kind of thing you see in American movies where the Air Force hotshot is insubordinate to Army officers because they're literally still senior officers in the same organization and have every right to issue punishments for insubordination. (Presumably there are regulations on officers making unrealistic demands of people outside their area of training so you don't get a navy captain dictating ground operations to a company of army folks, and when you get to the actual US military, there's probably regulations in every service that require an appropriate level of civility when talking to members of other services who are of higher equivalent rank)

Point is, I'd thought that using "Royal Canadian Air Force" was technically improper, except in discussing the history of Canadian Warfare involving the Second World War, and several years of relative inaction before and since. However, it seems that is no longer the case.

You can then more safely push your equipment to its limits and minimizing the potential for catastrophe.  This is really fascinating.

You might be interested in the book Nautilus 90 North, about the first voyage under the ice, done by USS Nautilus in 1958. One of their problems was that magnetic and gyrocompasses don't work that far north, so they needed a special compass---no GPS in 1958, of course. Another problem was that the realized at the last minute that they need something---anti-freeze I think---that the navy didn't have on hand, so they sent sailors to every gas station in Seattle, and emptied them of anti-freeze. Since the mission was secret, they couldn't explain why they needed all the anti-freeze, which must have raised some eyebrows.
Exciting!

It's nice to see a physicist's perspective on all of this, after Destin did his high-quality engineer's POV two years ago. I know that all of this is US Military soft power, but I don't particularly care. Science is being done, and if that science happens to have military applications (as it does), so be it. We need to know how climate change is affecting arctic conditions, and militaries the world over have recognized this threat far faster than the governments they answer to, and take it far more seriously (which tells you a lot about the way the world works). The idealist in me is resentful, but the realist is thankful that someone is doing this work. Maybe governments will listen (for a change)...but the cynic in me knows they won't.
